awd_titl_txt: Conference: SICB 2023 Symposium: Large-scale phenomena arising from small-scale biophysical processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award partially supports expenses for participants in a symposium and a workshop at the January 2023 annual meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB). The symposium brings together biologists and engineers studying questions about emerging large-scale influences of single cells in different study systems. Single cells, despite their small size, can organize and behave in ways that have unexpected and wide-reaching consequences. For instance, the physical forces that exist between cells drive tissue formation and pave the way for the evolution of complex, multicellular organisms. Another very different example in which large-scale patterns emerge from individual-cell behavior lies in the swimming of single-celled algae; swimming helps them navigate the ocean environment and form vast communities visible from space. Of the eleven speakers and two symposium organizers, six are from groups underrepresented in science and nine are early-career investigators; the speakers will present and discuss the latest findings and techniques, marrying state-of-the-art field, laboratory, and mathematical approaches. The symposium topic integrates across scales and types of organisms, and addresses both physiological and biomechanical questions through experiments and modeling. There will also be a complementary workshop to discuss strategies for engaging in successful cross-disciplinary research to promote the use of mathematics, physics and engineering tools to address biological problems. Results from the meeting and workshop will be published in the Society’s journal, Integrative and Comparative Biology.

The emergence of large-scale patterns from small-scale behavior and physiology of single cells is a broad theme of research interest across multiple biological fields. Aiming to facilitate the exchange of expertise and to promote cross-disciplinary research, this symposium will bring together researchers working on biophysical processes across cellular, organismal, and evolutionary scales in both aquatic and terrestrial systems. The three main themes of the symposium are 1) how small-scale biomechanics shape tissue formation; 2) how small-scale biophysics shape ecological interactions; and 3) how physical forces shape the evolution of early life. As a part of the annual meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology in Austin, TX, in January 2023, this symposium highlights the work of early-career researchers from diverse backgrounds. In addition to research presentations, the organizers will host a workshop on best practices in cross-disciplinary research. Results from the symposium and workshop will be disseminated via publication in an issue of the journal Integrative and Comparative Biology, and the participants will produce a position paper about future directions in this interdisciplinary field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Funding from this award provided partial support for invited and complementary presenters for the symposium “Large-scale phenomena arising from small-scale biophysical processes” and the workshop “Scientists Crossing: Getting involved in cross-disciplinary research” at the 2023 Annual Meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB) in Austin, TX.

 

The invited speakers and the organizers discussed three main themes in this symposium. The themes are 1) how small-scale biomechanics shape tissue formation; 2) how small-scale biophysics shapes ecological interactions; and 3) how physical forces shape the evolution of early life. This symposium brought together scientists and engineers studying questions about emerging large-scale influences of single  organisms in different study systems. These systems ranged from bacteria and yeast to Hydra and Trichoplax, and all the way up to birds. The contributed talks highlighted an even larger variety of study systems from the biomechanics of hagfish slime to the physical principles underlying the foraging patterns of copepods and dinosaurs. This symposium illustrated how the advances in microscopy, videography, and computational techniques have enabled us to better understand the physical principles that shape complex biological phenomena and reiterated the importance of collaboration across disciplines. We also organized a complementary workshop focused on the experience of early career researchers (ECRs) interested in exploring topics beyond traditional discipline silos. Over 40 ECRs took part in the workshop, which was double the anticipated attendance.  Participants found the workshop well-organized, welcoming, and helpful. 

 

The symposium yielded 11 articles published in the December 2023 issue of the journal Integrative and Comparative Biology, including one article on how to promote cross-disciplinary research based on the roundtable discussion and workshop. Elevating scientists from traditionally under-represented groups in STEM was one of the project’s goals. Of our eleven invited symposium speakers, five of them were POC, five identified as female, and two came from low-income South Asian countries. Eight out of the eleven speakers were ECRs (graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and assistant professors).  We also ensured that different types of institutions were represented in our list of speakers: two of the speakers (and one of the co-organizers) teach at primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs). We also provided travel subsidies for three additional ECRs to participate in the conference. The workshop encouraged ECRs by cultivating a community that is willing to reach beyond their comfort zones and providing a toolkit to succeed in cross-disciplinary work. Collaborations between physicists, mathematicians, engineers and biologists ultimately help to address key questions in understanding the rules of life. 

 

The report includes two photos taken during the lunch workshop, showing participants participating in a jigsaw activity and the conference organizers laying out the rules of engagement in this community.
